Saint-Médard Church is a peaceful place with beautiful architecture and colorful stained glass windows, offering a calm and welcoming ambiance.

A historical and spiritual treasure to discover at the Saint-Médard church!  ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️  The church of Saint-Médard in Paris is a true architectural and spiritual gem that is definitely worth the detour. I had the chance to visit this magnificent church recently and my experience was nothing short of captivating.  As soon as I walked through the doors of the church, I was immediately struck by the beauty of its architecture. The details and ornaments adorning the interior are absolutely stunning. Gothic vaults, colorful stained glass windows and delicate sculptures create an atmosphere of mystery and spirituality.  The church of Saint-Médard is also known for its fascinating history. It dates back to the 5th century, and through the centuries it has witnessed many historical events. The paintings and frescoes that adorn the walls trace this rich history and offer a captivating glimpse into the past.  The atmosphere of contemplation that reigns in the church is truly unique. I had the chance to attend a mass during my visit, and the experience was deeply moving. The beauty of the liturgy and sacred music created an atmosphere of serenity and spiritual connection.  . Respect and tranquility are also preserved, which allows everyone to fully enjoy the visit and contemplation.  In conclusion, the church of Saint-Médard in Paris is a place of great architectural and spiritual beauty. Whether you are a history buff, a lover of sacred art or simply looking for moments of peace and reflection, this church will satisfy you. Don't miss the opportunity to discover this hidden treasure in the heart of Paris.
A parish always welcoming. A place of Peace and prayer to recharge your batteries near Jesus Christ in the heart of a very pleasant neighborhood.

A quiet church located in front of the plaza at the bottom of Rue Mouffetard. There are no tourists and it is very quiet, far from the hustle and bustle outside. The feeling of being gently welcomed is very comfortable.

The current building was built in the mid-15th or early 16th century on the foundations of the previous Romanesque building. The construction work, which was interrupted several times, was only completed in the 18th century. During the Wars of Religion in 1561, the so-called "Tuult of Saint-Médard" occurred, during which the church was invaded and devastated by Protestants.

I would say Parish rather than church, the atmosphere is so family-friendly, few people, pretty stained glass windows, very relaxing in a lively area Beautiful stained glass windows, priests available....  Recommended even if you are not a believer..... Built in the fourteenth century on an old Roman road, the Saint Medard Church is located...at the place where rue Mouffetard crossed the Bievre.... A chapel in the twelfth century would even have existed on the site of the current Church..............  Ransacked by the Protestants of the neighborhood in 1461...it was the place of pilgrimages, miraculous healings, exorcism sessions and collective hypnosis around the Jansenist Deacon Francois of Paris.......... The door was walled up, on which an anonymous hand inscribed... BY THE KING, FORBID GOD FROM PERFORMING A MIRACLE IN THIS PLACE..........
Very beautiful church, construction in phases, from Gothic to the Modern Era. Canvas by Zurbarán among others.

The church of Saint Medard is a Catholic place of worship in Paris, located on rue Mouffetard, on the left bank of the Seine, south-east of the Sainte-Geneviève mountain. Built between the 15th and 18th centuries, it is home to the parish of the same name which includes a part of the 5th arrondissement, where the church stands, as well as a part of the 13th. Since the law of separation of Churches from State of 1905, it has been the property of the Municipality of Paris. The church of Saint Medard was built in the neighborhood which, until the Revolution, was called Faubourg Saint-Marceau and in which numerous churches once located nearby disappeared during the Revolution and with the transformation of Paris under the Second Empire. The plan of the church reflects its history with three homogeneous complexes dated respectively to the mid-15th century, to the period 1562-1620 and to the 18th century, the oldest parts being located at the level of the western facade and the adjacent bays and the most modern ones at the level of the apse. The exterior of the church was cleared of houses in the years 1868-1869. Starting from the first three bays of the Flamboyant Gothic nave from the end of the 15th century, we discover a choir that was enlarged in the 16th century, remodeled in the 17th and 18th centuries and covered with a wooden vault, unique in Paris, which was originally temporary but which is still in place today. The nave is adorned with five keystones with images. The alterations are particularly evident at the level of the capitals illustrating the Gothic, the Renaissance and the Classical.

The church is much deeper and wider than you might imagine from its narrow frontage. The extremely elaborate interior decoration will catch your eye. Although the Rue Mouffetard Market is right in front of the church, it is a very lively environment, but inside the church it is completely tranquil.

A very large 15th century church, one of the most beautiful in the city and little known by tourists. Located in a very characteristic neighborhood of Paris, in Rue Mouffetard. The priests personally take care of the church and are very helpful and welcoming. A church of great charm, a soft light filtered through the splendid windows, lots of silence and a great atmosphere. The paintings are beautiful and each work of art is completed by its own explanatory caption.
Very beautiful church with an unusual style. The father leads very lively masses! Very pleasant experience

The St Médard church is an old church in the Mouffetard district, a popular Parisian district. Blessed Sister Rosalie, daughter of Charity, exercised her happy influence there in the 19th century, for the benefit of the poor and the rich, intervening in particular during the popular revolutions of 1830 and 1848.

A Christmas mass at 6:30 p.m. perfect for the little ones. Lots of people. In the current situation in France that is reassuring. Thank you for succeeding in bringing together the faithful of our religion.
